questions.question_text_1: Why is using the GET method for sensitive data discouraged?

options.option_text: Data becomes part of browser history and URL
It uses a separate request header

questions.question_text_1: A login form doesn't show any message when users enter wrong credentials. Which Nielsen heuristic is violated?
question_texts: A login form doesn't show any message when users enter wrong credentials. Which Nielsen heuristic is violated?

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following are handled by the browser and not the Flask server?

questions.question_text_1: A user downloads a 10 MB file from a server with 5 Mbps speed. How long does it approximately take?

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** for the **"Diploma Level: Modern Application Development I"** exam, along with **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships. --- --- ## **Core Topics & Concepts Summary** ### **1. Flask (Python Web Framework)** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Routing & Views**: - `@app.route('/path')` decorators define URL endpoints. - Trailing slashes (`/about/` vs `/about`) trigger **301 redirects** if mismatched. - Dynamic routes: `/user/` or `/post/`. - **Request Methods**: - `GET`: Fetch data (data visible in URL; **not secure for sensitive data**). - `POST`: Submit data (data hidden in request body; preferred for sensitive data). - `PUT`, `DELETE`: Update/delete resources. - **Templates (Jinja2)**: - Inheritance: `{% extends "base.html" %}` + `{% block content %}`. - **Error**: Content must be inside blocks to render (e.g., `

` in `{% block content %}`). - **Flask-SQLAlchemy**: - **Relationships**: `db.relationship('Model', backref='field', cascade="all, delete")`. - `cascade="all, delete"`: Deleting a parent (e.g., `Author`) deletes children (e.g., `Book`). - **Lazy Loading**: - `lazy='dynamic'`: Returns a **query object** (filterable later) instead of loading all records. - **Error Handling**: - `abort(404)`: Return HTTP errors (e.g., 400, 404, 422). - Custom messages: `abort(404, "Course not found")`. - **Flask-RESTful**: - Define resources with `GET`, `POST`, `PUT`, `DELETE` methods. - **Method Signature Mismatch**: E.g., `POST /courses/CS101` fails if the method expects `(course_code, student_id)`. #### **Key Code Snippets:** ```python # Dynamic route with type conversion @app.route('/user/') def show_user(user_id): return f"User ID: {user_id}" # Query parameters marks = request.args.get('marks', default=0, type=int) # SQLAlchemy relationship (cascade delete) class Author(db.Model): books = db.relationship('Book', cascade="all, delete") # Flask-RESTful resource class StudentResource(Resource): def get(self, student_id): return {"id": student_id} ``` --- ### **2. Git & Version Control** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Branching/Merging**: - Merge `feature1` and `feature2` into `main`: ```bash git checkout main git merge feature1 git merge feature2 ``` - **Conflict Resolution**: - If remote has changes, `git push` fails. **Fix**: `git pull` first, resolve conflicts, then push. - **Git Commands**: - `git status`: Check changes. - `git add .`: Stage all files. - `git commit -m "message"`: Commit changes. - `git push`: Upload to remote. - `git pull`: Fetch + merge remote changes. --- ### **3. HTML/CSS/JavaScript** #### **Key Concepts:** - **HTML Structure**: - Block vs. Inline Elements: - Block: `
`, `

`, `

` (new line). - Inline: ``, ``, `` (same line). - **CSS Styling**: - **Border**: `border: 1px solid black;` (not `border-colour`). - **Font Weight**: `style.fontWeight = "bold"` (JS) or `font-weight: bold;` (CSS). - **JavaScript DOM Manipulation**: - Change input style: ```javascript document.getElementById("txt1").style.fontWeight = "bold"; ``` --- ### **4. SQLAlchemy & Databases** #### **Key Concepts:** - **CRUD Operations**: - Create: `db.session.add(obj)` - Update: `obj.field = "new_value"; db.session.commit()` - Delete: `db.session.delete(obj)` - **Querying**: - `Student.query.filter_by(id=2).first()`: Fetch single record. - `lazy='dynamic'`: Returns a query object for later filtering. --- ### **5. HTTP & APIs** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Status Codes**: - `200 OK`: Success. - `201 Created`: Resource created (e.g., `POST`). - `204 No Content`: Success, no response body (e.g., `DELETE`). - `400 Bad Request`: Invalid input. - `404 Not Found`: Resource missing. - `422 Unprocessable Entity`: Semantic errors (e.g., short query). - **RESTful Design**: - Endpoints: `/students` (collection) vs `/students/123` (single resource). - Methods: `GET` (read), `POST` (create), `PUT` (update), `DELETE` (remove). --- ### **6. Testing (Pytest)** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Test Naming**: Files/functions must start with `test_`. - **Markers**: - `@pytest.mark.unit`: Label tests. - Run specific tests: `pytest -m "unit"`. - **Fixtures**: Simulate isolated environments (e.g., test databases). - **Assertions**: ```python assert multiply(3, 4) == 12 ``` --- ### **7. Performance & Networking** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Bandwidth Calculation**: - **Time = Data Size / Speed** - Example: 10 MB file at 5 Mbps (0.625 MB/s) → `10 / 0.625 = 16 seconds`. - **GET vs. POST**: - `GET`: Data in URL (visible, cached, bookmarked). - `POST`: Data in body (hidden, secure for sensitive data). --- ### **8. Usability Heuristics (Nielsen)** #### **Key Principles:** 1. **Visibility of System Status**: Keep users informed (e.g., show error messages for wrong credentials). 2. **Error Prevention**: Design to minimize mistakes. 3. **Recognition Over Recall**: Make options visible (e.g., dropdowns vs. free-text input). --- ### **9. Frontend vs. Backend** | **Handled by Browser** | **Handled by Flask Server** | |-------------------------------|-----------------------------| | Parsing HTML/CSS | URL routing | | JavaScript execution | Database queries | | Auto-filling forms | Business logic | | DOM manipulation | Template rendering | --- ### **10. Logging & Debugging** #### **Key Concepts:** - **Python Logging Levels**: - `DEBUG` (detailed info) → `INFO` → `WARNING` → `ERROR` → `CRITICAL`. - **Example**: ```python logging.basicConfig(level=logging.WARNING) logging.error("Negative number: %d", num) # Logs if level >= WARNING ``` --- --- ## **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs** ### **1. Flask Core Concepts** ```mermaid graph TD A[Flask] --> B[Routing] A --> C[Templates Jinja2] A --> D[Request Handling] A --> E[Database SQLAlchemy] B --> B1["@app.route('/path')"] B --> B2["Dynamic Routes: /user/"] B --> B3["Trailing Slash Redirects"] C --> C1["{% extends 'base.html' %}"] C --> C2["{% block content %}"] C --> C3["Template Inheritance"] D --> D1[GET/POST Methods] D --> D2[Query Parameters: request.args] D --> D3[Form Data: request.form] E --> E1[Models: db.Model] E --> E2[Relationships: db.relationship] E --> E3[Lazy Loading: lazy='dynamic'] ``` ### **2. Git Workflow** ```mermaid graph LR A[Local Changes] -->|git add| B[Staging] B -->|git commit| C[Local Repository] C -->|git push| D[Remote Repository] D -->|git pull| C C -->|Conflict?| E[Resolve Conflicts] E --> C ``` ### **3. HTTP Methods & Status Codes** ```mermaid graph TD A[HTTP Methods] --> B[GET] A --> C[POST] A --> D[PUT] A --> E[DELETE] B --> B1[200 OK] B --> B2[404 Not Found] C --> C1[201 Created] C --> C2[400 Bad Request] D --> D1[200 OK] E --> E1[204 No Content] ``` ### **4. Testing Pyramid** ```mermaid graph TD A[Testing] --> B[Unit Tests] A --> C[Integration Tests] A --> D[System Tests] A --> E[Acceptance Tests] B --> B1["Test functions (e.g., multiply())"] C --> C1["Test component interactions"] D --> D1["Test full system"] E --> E1["Test with real users"] ``` ### **5. Frontend vs. Backend** ```mermaid graph LR A[Browser] -->|Renders| B[HTML/CSS] A -->|Executes| C[JavaScript] A -->|Sends| D[HTTP Requests] D --> E[Flask Server] E -->|Processes| F[Routes] E -->|Queries| G[Database] E -->|Renders| H[Templates] E -->|Returns| D ``` --- ## **Key Equations (Math/Performance)** 1. **Bandwidth Time Calculation**: \[ \text{Time (seconds)} = \frac{\text{Data Size (MB)}}{\text{Speed (MB/s)}} \] - Example: 10 MB at 5 Mbps (0.625 MB/s) → \( \frac{10}{0.625} = 16 \) seconds. 2. **Modulo Operation** (from Flask routes): \[ a \% b = \text{Remainder of } a \div b \] - Example: `4 % 5 = 4`.
